statement: Right to Education is a Fundamental Right under Article 21A
explanation: Article 21A makes free and compulsory education for children aged 6-14 a fundamental right.

statement: The Constitution of India was adopted on 26th January 1950
explanation: The Constitution was adopted on 26th November 1949 and came into effect on 26th January 1950.

statement: India has a Presidential form of government
explanation: India has a Parliamentary form of government with a Prime Minister as the head of government.

statement: Article 32 is called the 'Heart and Soul of the Constitution'
explanation: Dr. Ambedkar called Article 32 (Right to Constitutional Remedies) the heart and soul of the Constitution.

statement: The President of India is the Supreme Commander of Armed Forces
explanation: Article 53 makes the President the Supreme Commander of the Defence Forces of India.

statement: Fundamental Duties were originally part of the Constitution
explanation: Fundamental Duties were added by the 42nd Amendment in 1976, based on recommendations of the Swaran Singh Committee.

statement: Right to Property is still a Fundamental Right
explanation: Right to Property was removed as a Fundamental Right by the 44th Amendment in 1978 and made a Constitutional right under Article 300A.

statement: Rajya Sabha members are directly elected by people
explanation: Rajya Sabha members are indirectly elected by the elected members of State Legislative Assemblies.

statement: Article 19 guarantees six freedoms to citizens
explanation: Article 19 guarantees six freedoms including speech, assembly, association, movement, residence, and profession.

statement: The Constitution can never be amended
explanation: Article 368 provides the procedure for amending the Constitution, making it a flexible document.

statement: The Directive Principles are justiciable in court
explanation: Directive Principles are non-justiciable, meaning they cannot be enforced by courts, but are fundamental in governance.

statement: The Indian Constitution is the longest written constitution in the world
explanation: The Indian Constitution is the world's longest written constitution with 448 articles in 25 parts and 12 schedules.

statement: A person can be President of India only once
explanation: There is no limit on the number of terms a person can serve as President. They can be re-elected.

statement: The Supreme Court has the power of Judicial Review
explanation: The Supreme Court can review and strike down laws and actions that violate the Constitution.

statement: Emergency can be declared only by Parliament
explanation: Emergency is declared by the President, though it must be approved by Parliament within specific timeframes.
